user_questions.text: how can i make liquid culture? should i use dextrose or barley malt powder?
if i have a jar of agar that is contaminated, should i autoclave it and use it or toss it and start afresh?
how bad is it that my mushroom grain bag is contaminated with some green is it possible it'll still work?
i think my pressure cooker only goes to 8psi what can i do?
which is easier/better slaked lime or 12% hydrogen peroxide?

user_statements.text: i have both [dextrose and barley malt], should i use both?
where can i buy Calcium Hydroxide in france?

tensions.description: Balancing faster methods (chemical pasteurization) vs traditional methods (pressure cooking) for sterilization

beliefs: Mushroom cultivation is learnable through experimentation and iteration
Chemical alternatives can substitute for expensive equipment
Contamination is manageable with proper technique
Optimization requires comparing multiple approaches systematically
mental_models: Scientific method: test variables systematically (dextrose vs malt)
Iterative problem-solving: encounter issue → research solution → adjust
Resource optimization: work with available equipment (8 PSI cooker)

notes: MAJOR PROJECT DISCOVERY: This 90-message, 26-hour conversation reveals deep engagement with mushroom cultivation. This is not casual interest - Bilal is setting up a serious home cultivation system with liquid culture, agar plates, grain bags, and multiple sterilization methods. The intensity and technical depth suggests this is flow state work. Location marker: France. This connects to DIY/maker values seen in earlier conversations but at much greater scale and commitment.
